# First Notes on the High E (E–F–G)

Welcome! In this lesson you’ll play your very first fretted notes on guitar using the **high E string**. You’ll learn correct finger placement, basic **alternate picking (down–up)**, and a clean E–F–G pattern.

**You will learn to:**
- Produce a clear tone with proper fretting-hand position
- Use **index on 1st fret (F)** and **ring on 3rd fret (G)**
- Start alternate picking at a steady tempo
- Practice clean, even **E–F–G** timing with a metronome.

## Setup & Posture

- Sit or stand tall; shoulders relaxed.
- **Pick grip:** hold a medium pick between the side of your index finger and the pad of your thumb; about **2–3 mm** of the tip showing.
- **Fretting hand:** fingers **curved**, wrist neutral, **thumb behind the neck** (roughly opposite the 2nd finger).
- Aim to **press just behind the fret** (toward the body) to avoid buzzing.
Close-up of a correct guitar pick grip with slight pick tip exposed
_Correct pick grip:_ relaxed hand, small pick tip exposed, pick angled slightly for smooth string contact.

## First Fretted Note: F

1. Pluck the **open high E** (thinnest string) to hear its pitch.
2. Place your **index finger (1)** just **behind the 1st fret** on the high E.
3. Press **firmly but lightly**—enough to stop the buzz, no more.
4. Pick **down** then **up** to begin **alternate picking**.

## Next Note: G on the 3rd Fret

- Use your **ring finger (3)** on the **3rd fret** of the high E for **G**.
- Keep the knuckle curved and land on the **tip** of the finger.
- Maintain alternate picking: **down–up–down–up**.

## Core Pattern: E–F–G

Play these slowly and evenly. Start at **60 BPM** and only speed up when every note rings clearly.

```
TAB (high E string only):
E|--0--1--3--|--3--1--0--|
     E  F  G    G  F  E
```
**Pro tip:** lift and place as **little** as possible; keep movements efficient.

## Rhythm Variations

Try each for 1–2 minutes at 60 BPM:
- **Quarter notes:** pick **D U D U** across four clicks (1 2 3 4).
- **Eighth notes:** two picks per click (**1 & 2 & 3 & 4 &**) with **D U**.
- **Three-note loop:** E–F–G repeatedly in eighth notes.
- **Accent the 1:** make the first note slightly louder each bar to build timing awareness.

## Common Mistakes & Fixes

- **Buzzing notes:** move closer to the fret and press slightly firmer.
- **Muted string:** curl the fingertip more so it doesn’t touch adjacent strings.
- **Uneven timing:** return to quarter notes; count out loud.
- **Tense hand:** shake out the hand; tension kills speed and tone.
Side view of relaxed seated guitar posture with neutral wrists
Relaxed posture helps tone and endurance. Keep wrists neutral; avoid collapsing the fretting-hand thumb over the neck.

## 5-Minute Micro-Routine

1. :60 — Open high E with **D U** picking (focus on smoothness).
2. :90 — **F** (1st fret) clean tone reps; 4 counts each.
3. :90 — **G** (3rd fret) clean tone reps; 4 counts each.
4. :60 — Loop **E–F–G** in eighth notes at 60 BPM.
5. :30 — Cool-down: slow quarter notes, perfect tone.

## Next Steps

- Add the **2nd fret (F#)** with your **middle finger (2)** and play **E–F–F#–G**.
- Try **60 → 72 → 80 BPM**. Only increase when the tone is clean and timing is even.
Finger for F
Which finger should play the **1st fret (F)** on the high E string in this lesson?
Index (1)
Middle (2)
Ring (3)
Use **index** for 1st fret to keep hand position consistent for beginners.
Note Order
What is the ascending note order you practice on the high E in this lesson?
E – F – G
E – F# – G#
C – D – E
Open E, 1st-fret F, 3rd-fret G.
Fret Placement
Where should your fingertip be for the cleanest tone?
Just behind the fret (toward the body)
Exactly on top of the fret wire
In the middle of the fret space (far from the fret)
Close to the fret reduces string rattle and buzz.
Finger for G
Which finger plays **G** on the **3rd fret** of the high E in this lesson?
Ring (3)
Index (1)
Little (4)
Ring finger on 3rd fret keeps spacing natural for beginners.
Alternate Picking
What best describes **alternate picking**?
Alternating **down** and **up** strokes in sequence
Only downstrokes at all times
Random stroke directions
Down–up–down–up builds efficiency and speed.
Starting Tempo
What starting metronome tempo does the lesson recommend?
60 BPM
140 BPM
200 BPM
Start slow to ensure clean tone and even rhythm.
Tone Tip
Which action most helps produce a **clean** note?
Curved fingertip close to the fret
Flattening the finger pad across the string
Placing the finger directly on top of the fret wire
Curved fingertip and proximity to the fret reduce buzzing and muting.
Counting Eighths
In **4/4** time at 60 BPM, how many **eighth-note** picks occur in one bar?
Eighth notes are two per beat; 4 beats × 2 = 8.
Fix the Buzz
Your **F** is buzzing. What’s the **best** first fix to try?
Move closer to the fret and press a touch firmer
Move farther from the fret and press harder
Ignore it and play faster
Placement near the fret improves tone with less effort.
Stroke Order
For two eighth notes in a row, which picking is correct for **alternate picking**?
Down then Up
Up then Up
Down then Down
Alternating directions (D–U) keeps motion economical.
